questions.question: Discuss the principle, working, and applications of the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride. Also explain the reactions at both electrodes and the industrial significance of this process.
questions.correctAnswer: Electrolysis of molten NaCl involves Na⁺ reduced to Na at cathode, Cl⁻ oxidised to Cl₂ at anode; used industrially for sodium and chlorine production.
questions.solution:
Electrolysis of Molten Sodium Chloride (Down's Process):

Principle: Electrolysis is the process of decomposing an electrolyte by passing an electric current through it in the molten/dissolved state. In molten NaCl, Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions are free to move and can be discharged at respective electrodes.

Dissociation of NaCl (in molten state): $$\text{NaCl} \rightarrow \text{Na}^+ + \text{Cl}^-$$

Working (Down's Cell): A cylindrical steel cell with a carbon (graphite) anode and a steel cathode (ring-shaped). A diaphragm (iron gauze) separates the products to prevent recombination. Molten NaCl (m.p. 801°C) is taken; CaCl₂ is often added to lower the melting point. Direct current (DC) is passed through molten NaCl.

Electrode Reactions:
At Cathode (reduction): $$\text{Na}^+ + e^- \rightarrow \text{Na (l)}$$ (Sodium metal is deposited as liquid, collected.)
At Anode (oxidation): $$2\text{Cl}^- \rightarrow \text{Cl}_2\text{(g)} + 2e^-$$ (Chlorine gas is evolved at the anode.)

Overall Cell Reaction: $$2\text{NaCl} \rightarrow 2\text{Na} + \text{Cl}_2$$

Industrial Significance: 1. Sodium metal is used as a reducing agent in metallurgy, in making tetraethyl lead (antiknock agent), and in sodium vapour lamps. 2. Chlorine gas is used in water purification, manufacture of PVC, bleaching agents (bleaching powder, NaOCl), and disinfectants. 3. The process is the main industrial source of both elemental sodium and chlorine gas.

questions.question:
(a)
(i) At the same temperature, CO₂ gas is more soluble in water than O₂ gas. Which one of them will have a higher value of K_H and why? (1 mark)
(ii) How does the size of blood cells change when placed in an aqueous solution containing more than 0.9% (mass/volume) sodium chloride? (1 mark)
(iii) 1 molal aqueous solution of an electrolyte A₂B₃ is 60% ionized. Calculate the boiling point of the solution. (Given: $K_b$ for H₂O $= 0.52\ \text{K kg mol}^{-1}$) (3 marks)
questions.correctAnswer: (i) O₂ has higher K_H; (ii) Blood cells shrink (crenation); (iii) Boiling point = 101.768°C
questions.solution:
(i) Henry's Law states: p = K_H · x. A higher K_H means lower solubility. Since CO₂ is more soluble than O₂, CO₂ has a lower K_H, and O₂ has the higher K_H.

(ii) A solution containing more than 0.9% (m/v) NaCl is hypertonic relative to the blood cell fluid. When blood cells are placed in a hypertonic solution, water moves out of the cells into the surrounding solution by osmosis. This causes the cells to lose water and shrink — a process called crenation.

(iii) Dissociation of A₂B₃: $$\text{A}_2\text{B}_3 \rightarrow 2\text{A}^{3+} + 3\text{B}^{2-}$$ Total particles per formula unit: n = 2 + 3 = 5.

van't Hoff factor: $$i = 1 + \alpha(n - 1) = 1 + 0.60 \times (5 - 1) = 1 + 2.4 = 3.4$$

Elevation in boiling point: $$\Delta T_b = i \cdot K_b \cdot m = 3.4 \times 0.52 \times 1 = 1.768\ \text{K}$$

Boiling point of solution: $$T_b = 100 + 1.768 = 101.768°\text{C}$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
(b)
(i) The vapour pressures of A and B at 25°C are 75 mm Hg and 25 mm Hg, respectively. If A and B are mixed such that the mole fraction of A in the mixture is 0.4, calculate the mole fraction of B in the vapour phase. (2 marks)
(ii) Define colligative property. Which colligative property is preferred for the molar mass determination of macromolecules? (2 marks)
(iii) Why are equimolar solutions of sodium chloride and glucose not isotonic? (1 mark)
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (i) Mole fraction of B in vapour phase = 0.33; (ii) Colligative property depends only on number of solute particles; osmotic pressure is preferred for macromolecules; (iii) NaCl dissociates giving i=2, while glucose does not dissociate (i=1), so they have different osmotic pressures.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Given: P°A = 75 mm Hg, P°B = 25 mm Hg, xA = 0.4, xB = 0.6.

Using Raoult's Law: $$P_A = x_A \cdot P°_A = 0.4 \times 75 = 30\ \text{mm Hg}$$ $$P_B = x_B \cdot P°_B = 0.6 \times 25 = 15\ \text{mm Hg}$$ $$P_{\text{total}} = 30 + 15 = 45\ \text{mm Hg}$$

Mole fraction of A in vapour phase: $$y_A = \frac{P_A}{P_{\text{total}}} = \frac{30}{45} = 0.67$$

Mole fraction of B in vapour phase: $$y_B = 1 - 0.67 = 0.33$$

(ii) Colligative Property: A colligative property is a property of a solution that depends only on the number (concentration) of solute particles present in the solution, and not on the nature or identity of the solute. Examples include: relative lowering of vapour pressure, elevation of boiling point, depression of freezing point, and osmotic pressure.

Osmotic pressure is the preferred colligative property for determining the molar mass of macromolecules because even very dilute solutions of macromolecules produce a measurable osmotic pressure, whereas the other colligative effects are too small to measure accurately at such low concentrations.

(iii) Glucose does not dissociate in water → i = 1. NaCl dissociates completely: NaCl → Na⁺ + Cl⁻ → i = 2. Since NaCl solution has twice as many particles as glucose solution at the same molarity, its osmotic pressure is approximately twice that of the glucose solution (π = iMRT). Therefore, equimolar solutions of NaCl and glucose are not isotonic.

questions.question:
Answer any five of the following:

(a) N,N-diethyl-benzenesulphonamide is insoluble in alkali. Give reason.
(b) Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction. Why?
(c) Write a simple chemical test to distinguish between methylamine and aniline.
(d) Write the chemical reaction involved in Gabriel phthalimide synthesis.
questions.correctAnswer: (a) No N–H hydrogen present to react with alkali; (b) Lone pair on N forms complex with AlCl₃ deactivating the catalyst; (c) Nitrous acid test: methylamine gives N₂ effervescence, aniline gives stable diazonium salt that couples with β-naphthol to give orange-red azo dye; (d) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis involves reaction of phthalimide with KOH, then alkyl halide, then hydrolysis to give primary amine.
questions.solution:
(a) In N,N-diethylbenzenesulphonamide, the nitrogen atom has no hydrogen atom attached to it (both N–H positions are replaced by ethyl groups). Since there is no acidic N–H hydrogen, the compound cannot react with alkali (NaOH) to form a water-soluble sodium salt. Therefore, it remains insoluble in alkali. (Note: Primary sulphonamides R–SO₂–NH₂ and secondary sulphonamides R–SO₂–NHR' dissolve in alkali because their N–H is sufficiently acidic to be deprotonated.)

(b) Friedel-Crafts reactions require a Lewis acid catalyst such as AlCl₃. Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reactions because: 1) The lone pair on the nitrogen of aniline acts as a Lewis base and forms a stable acid-base complex with AlCl₃: C₆H₅NH₂ + AlCl₃ → C₆H₅NH₂·AlCl₃⁻. This deactivates and consumes the catalyst. 2) The resulting anilinium salt makes the ring electron-poor (–NH₃⁺ is a deactivating group), preventing the electrophilic substitution needed for Friedel-Crafts.

(c) Use the nitrous acid (HNO₂) test — treat with NaNO₂ + HCl at 0–5°C: Methylamine (primary aliphatic amine) reacts with HNO₂ to form an unstable diazonium salt that immediately decomposes, releasing N₂ gas with effervescence and forming methanol: CH₃NH₂ + HNO₂ → CH₃OH + N₂↑ + H₂O. Aniline (primary aromatic amine) reacts with HNO₂ at 0–5°C to form a stable diazonium salt (benzenediazonium chloride). When coupled with β-naphthol, an intense orange-red azo dye is formed — a positive test. The formation of a stable diazonium salt (confirmed by azo coupling) identifies aniline; the immediate effervescence of N₂ identifies methylamine.

(d) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis involves: Step 1 — Phthalimide reacts with KOH to form potassium phthalimide (K⁺ salt). Step 2 — Potassium phthalimide reacts with an alkyl halide (R–X) via SN2 to give N-alkylphthalimide. Step 3 — N-alkylphthalimide undergoes acid or alkaline hydrolysis to give a primary amine (R–NH₂) and phthalic acid. This method is used to prepare pure primary amines free from secondary and tertiary amines.

questions.question:
(a)
(i) State Kohlrausch's law of independent migration of ions. Write an expression for the limiting molar conductivity of acetic acid according to Kohlrausch's law.

(ii) Calculate the maximum work and $\log K_c$ for the given reaction at 298 K:
$$\text{Ni(s)} + 2\text{Ag}^+(\text{aq}) \rightarrow \text{Ni}^{2+}(\text{aq}) + 2\text{Ag(s)}$$
Given: $E^\circ_{\text{Ni}^{2+}/\text{Ni}} = -0.25\ \text{V}$, $E^\circ_{\text{Ag}^+/\text{Ag}} = +0.80\ \text{V}$
questions.correctAnswer: (i) At infinite dilution, molar conductivity of an electrolyte = sum of individual ionic conductivities: $\Lambda_m^\circ = \nu_+ \lambda_+^\circ + \nu_- \lambda_-^\circ$. For acetic acid: $\Lambda_m^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}) = \lambda^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COO}^-) + \lambda^\circ(\text{H}^+)$. (ii) $E^\circ_{\text{cell}} = 1.05\ \text{V}$; $W_{\text{max}} = -\Delta G^\circ = nFE^\circ_{\text{cell}} = 2 \times 96500 \times 1.05 \approx 202650\ \text{J}$; $\log K_c = nE^\circ_{\text{cell}}/0.0591 \approx 35.5$
questions.solution:
(i) **Kohlrausch's Law of Independent Migration of Ions:** At infinite dilution (limiting condition), the molar conductivity of an electrolyte can be expressed as the sum of the individual contributions of the cation and anion, and each ion makes a definite and independent contribution to the total molar conductivity regardless of the nature of the other ion present.

Mathematically:
$$\Lambda_m^\circ = \nu_+ \lambda_+^\circ + \nu_- \lambda_-^\circ$$

**Expression for acetic acid ($\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}$):**
$$\Lambda_m^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}) = \lambda^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COO}^-) + \lambda^\circ(\text{H}^+)$$
This can also be expressed using strong electrolytes:
$$\Lambda_m^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}) = \Lambda_m^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COONa}) + \Lambda_m^\circ(\text{HCl}) - \Lambda_m^\circ(\text{NaCl})$$

(ii) **Calculating $E^\circ_{\text{cell}}$:**
$$E^\circ_{\text{cell}} = E^\circ_{\text{cathode}} - E^\circ_{\text{anode}} = E^\circ_{\text{Ag}^+/\text{Ag}} - E^\circ_{\text{Ni}^{2+}/\text{Ni}}$$
$$E^\circ_{\text{cell}} = +0.80 - (-0.25) = 1.05\ \text{V}$$

**Maximum work** (equal to $-\Delta G^\circ$):
$$W_{\text{max}} = -\Delta G^\circ = nFE^\circ_{\text{cell}}$$
$$W_{\text{max}} = 2 \times 96500 \times 1.05 = 202650\ \text{J} \approx 202.65\ \text{kJ}$$

**$\log K_c$:**
$$\Delta G^\circ = -RT\ln K_c = -2.303RT\log K_c$$
Also, $\Delta G^\circ = -nFE^\circ_{\text{cell}}$, so:
$$\log K_c = \frac{nE^\circ_{\text{cell}}}{0.0591} = \frac{2 \times 1.05}{0.0591} = \frac{2.10}{0.0591} \approx 35.5$$

questions.question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:

Amines constitute an important class of organic compounds derived by replacing one or more hydrogen atoms of ammonia molecule by alkyl/aryl groups. Amines are usually formed from nitro compounds, halides, amides, etc. They exhibit hydrogen bonding which influences their physical properties. Alkyl amines are found to be stronger bases than ammonia. In aromatic amines, electron releasing and withdrawing groups, respectively increase and decrease their basic character. Reactions of amines are governed by availability of the unshared pair of electrons on nitrogen. Influence of the number of hydrogen atoms at nitrogen atom on the type of reactions and nature of products is responsible for identification and distinction between primary, secondary and tertiary amines. Reactivity of aromatic amines can be controlled by acylation process.

(i) Why does aniline not give Friedel-Crafts reaction?

(ii) Arrange the following in the increasing order of their $pK_b$ values:
$$C_6H_5NH_2,\ NH_3,\ C_2H_5NH_2,\ (CH_3)_3N$$

(iii) How can you distinguish between $CH_3CH_2NH_2$ and $(CH_3CH_2)_2NH$ by Hinsberg test?

(iv) Write the structures of A and B in the following reactions:

(I) Nitrobenzene reacting with Sn + HCl to give A, then A reacting with $Br_2$ water to give B

(II) $$CH_3CH_2CONH_2 \xrightarrow{Br_2/alc.\ KOH} A \xrightarrow{CH_3COCl,\ Pyridine} B$$
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Lone pair on N coordinates with Lewis acid $AlCl_3$, deactivating the catalyst and ring.
(ii) $C_6H_5NH_2 > NH_3 > (CH_3)_3N > C_2H_5NH_2$ (increasing $pK_b$)
(iii) $CH_3CH_2NH_2$ forms alkali-soluble sulfonamide; $(CH_3CH_2)_2NH$ forms alkali-insoluble sulfonamide.
(iv)(I) A: $C_6H_5NH_2$; B: $C_6H_4(NH_2)Br$ (ortho/para-bromoaniline)
(iv)(II) A: $CH_3CH_2NH_2$; B: $CH_3CH_2NHCOCH_3$
questions.solution:
(i) Aniline does not give the Friedel-Crafts reaction because the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom coordinates with the Lewis acid catalyst (like $AlCl_3$), forming an acid-base complex. This makes the nitrogen unavailable and also deactivates the ring, making the reaction unfavourable.

(ii) Increasing order of $pK_b$ (decreasing basicity):
$$C_6H_5NH_2 > NH_3 > (CH_3)_3N > C_2H_5NH_2$$
(Higher $pK_b$ = weaker base; $C_6H_5NH_2$ is the weakest base with the highest $pK_b$, and $C_2H_5NH_2$ is the strongest base with the lowest $pK_b$ in aqueous solution.)

(iii) Hinsberg test:
- $CH_3CH_2NH_2$ (primary amine) reacts with Hinsberg reagent (benzenesulfonyl chloride, $C_6H_5SO_2Cl$) to form a sulfonamide that is soluble in alkali (NaOH), because the sulfonamide still has an acidic N–H proton.
- $(CH_3CH_2)_2NH$ (secondary amine) reacts with Hinsberg reagent to form an insoluble sulfonamide (no acidic N–H proton remains, so it does not dissolve in alkali).

(iv)(I):
- A: $C_6H_5NH_2$ (Aniline) — obtained by reduction of nitrobenzene with Sn + HCl
- B: $C_6H_4(NH_2)Br$ (ortho- or para-bromoaniline) — obtained by bromination of aniline with $Br_2$ water

(iv)(II):
- A: $CH_3CH_2NH_2$ (Ethylamine) — via Hoffmann bromamide degradation of propionamide
- B: $CH_3CH_2NHCOCH_3$ (N-ethylacetamide) — via acylation of ethylamine with $CH_3COCl$

alternativeQuestion.question:
How will you convert the following:

(i) Benzoic acid to aniline

(ii) Aniline to p-bromoaniline
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(i) Benzoic acid → Benzamide → Aniline
(ii) Aniline → Acetanilide → p-Bromoacetanilide → p-Bromoaniline
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Benzoic acid to aniline:
Step 1: Convert benzoic acid to benzamide:
$$C_6H_5COOH \xrightarrow{NH_3} C_6H_5CONH_2$$
Step 2: Apply Hoffmann bromamide degradation:
$$C_6H_5CONH_2 \xrightarrow{Br_2/KOH} C_6H_5NH_2 \quad \text{(Aniline)}$$
(Alternatively: $C_6H_5CONH_2 \xrightarrow{LiAlH_4} C_6H_5NH_2$)

(ii) Aniline to p-bromoaniline:
Step 1: Acetylate aniline to protect the –NH₂ group:
$$C_6H_5NH_2 \xrightarrow{CH_3COCl,\ Pyridine} C_6H_5NHCOCH_3$$
Step 2: Brominate the acetyl derivative (–NHCOCH₃ is ortho/para director; bulky group favours para):
$$C_6H_5NHCOCH_3 \xrightarrow{Br_2} C_6H_4(Br)NHCOCH_3 \quad \text{(para)}$$
Step 3: Hydrolyse to get p-bromoaniline:
$$C_6H_4(Br)NHCOCH_3 \xrightarrow{H_2O,\ H^+} C_6H_4(Br)NH_2 \quad \text{(p-bromoaniline)}$$

questions.question:
(A) Calculate $\Delta G^0$ for the reaction:

$$\text{Zn}_{(s)} + \text{Cu}^{2+}_{(aq)} = \text{Zn}^{2+}_{(aq)} + \text{Cu}_{(s)}$$

Given: $E^0$ for $\dfrac{\text{Zn}^{2+}}{\text{Zn}} = -0.76\text{ V}$ and $E^0$ for $\dfrac{\text{Cu}^{2+}}{\text{Cu}} = +0.34\text{ V}$

$R = 8.314 \text{ J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}$ and $F = 96500 \text{ C mol}^{-1}$

(B) Give two advantages of fuel cells.
questions.correctAnswer: (A) $\Delta G^0 = -212300 \text{ J/mol} = -212.3 \text{ kJ/mol}$ (B) High efficiency (~70%) and less pollution (water as only byproduct).
questions.solution:
(A)
Step 1: Identify anode and cathode:
- Anode (oxidation): Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻, $E^0_{\text{anode}} = -0.76\text{ V}$
- Cathode (reduction): Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu, $E^0_{\text{cathode}} = +0.34\text{ V}$

Step 2: Calculate $E^0_\text{cell}$:
$$E^0_\text{cell} = E^0_\text{cathode} - E^0_\text{anode} = +0.34 - (-0.76) = +1.10 \text{ V}$$

Step 3: Calculate $\Delta G^0$:
$$\Delta G^0 = -nFE^0_\text{cell}$$
Where $n = 2$ (2 electrons transferred):
$$\Delta G^0 = -2 \times 96500 \times 1.10$$
$$\Delta G^0 = -212300 \text{ J mol}^{-1} = -212.3 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$
The negative value confirms the reaction is spontaneous.

(B) Advantages of fuel cells:
1. High efficiency: Fuel cells convert chemical energy of fuels (like H₂) directly into electrical energy with higher efficiency (~70%) compared to conventional thermal power plants (~40%), as they are not limited by the Carnot cycle.
2. Less pollution: Fuel cells produce water as the only byproduct (when H₂ is used as fuel), causing negligible exhaust pollution compared to combustion engines, making them environmentally friendly.
3. (Additional) Fuel cells operate continuously as long as fuel is supplied, without requiring recharging like conventional batteries.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(A) Out of the following pairs, predict with reason which pair will allow greater conduction of electricity:
(i) Silver wire at 30°C or silver wire at 60°C
(ii) 0.1 M CH₃COOH solution or 1 M CH₃COOH solution
(iii) KCl solution at 20°C or KCl solution at 50°C

(B) Give two points of difference between electrochemical and electrolytic cells.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (A)(i) Silver wire at 30°C (ii) 0.1 M CH₃COOH (iii) KCl solution at 50°C (B) Electrochemical cell converts chemical → electrical energy (spontaneous); electrolytic cell converts electrical → chemical energy (non-spontaneous).
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(A)(i) Silver is a metallic conductor. As temperature increases, positive metal ions vibrate more intensely, causing greater resistance to electron flow. Silver wire at 30°C has lower resistance and thus greater conductance than at 60°C.

(A)(ii) CH₃COOH (acetic acid) is a weak electrolyte. The degree of ionisation ($\alpha$) is inversely related to concentration (Ostwald's dilution law): $\alpha = \sqrt{K_a/C}$. At lower concentration (0.1 M), the degree of ionisation is higher, meaning more ions are present in solution, giving greater conductance. Thus 0.1 M CH₃COOH has greater conductance than 1 M CH₃COOH.

(A)(iii) KCl is a strong electrolyte (ionic conductor in solution). The conductance of electrolytic solutions increases with temperature because higher temperature → lower viscosity → greater ionic mobility → greater conductance. Therefore KCl solution at 50°C has greater conductance than at 20°C.

(B) Differences between electrochemical and electrolytic cells:
| Property | Electrochemical (Galvanic) Cell | Electrolytic Cell |
|----------|---------------------------------|-------------------|
| 1. Energy conversion | Converts chemical energy → electrical energy (spontaneous redox reaction). | Converts electrical energy → chemical energy (non-spontaneous redox reaction driven by external source). |
| 2. Electrode polarity | Anode is negative (–); Cathode is positive (+). | Anode is positive (+); Cathode is negative (–). |
| 3. Spontaneity | Reaction is spontaneous ($\Delta G < 0$). | Reaction is non-spontaneous ($\Delta G > 0$). |
| 4. Example | Daniell cell, dry cell, fuel cell | Electrolysis of water, electroplating |

questions.question:
(A) Account for the following (1 × 3 = 3 Marks):
(i) Copper(I) compounds are colourless whereas Copper(II) compounds are coloured.

[Note: The full question text for Q36 parts (A)(ii), (A)(iii), and (B) were not fully provided in the source material. Only the beginning of Q36 is shown.]
questions.correctAnswer: Cu⁺ has completely filled 3d¹⁰ configuration (no d-d transition possible) → colourless. Cu²⁺ has 3d⁹ configuration with unpaired electron → d-d transition possible → coloured.
questions.solution:
Cu⁺ (Copper I): Electronic configuration: $[\text{Ar}]\ 3d^{10}\ 4s^0$ — completely filled d-orbitals. Since all d-orbitals are fully occupied, no d-d electronic transitions are possible. Therefore, Cu⁺ compounds do not absorb visible light and are colourless.

Cu²⁺ (Copper II): Electronic configuration: $[\text{Ar}]\ 3d^9\ 4s^0$ — incompletely filled d-orbitals with one unpaired electron. d-d electronic transitions are possible, allowing absorption of specific wavelengths of visible light. The complementary colour is reflected/transmitted, making Cu²⁺ compounds coloured (typically blue/green).

questions.question:
$E^\circ_{cell}$ for the given redox reaction is 2.71 V:

$$Mg_{(s)} + Cu^{2+}_{(0.01\ M)} \longrightarrow Mg^{2+}_{(0.001\ M)} + Cu_{(s)}$$

Calculate $E_{cell}$ for the reaction. Write the direction of flow of current when an external opposite potential applied is:
(i) less than 2.71 V
(ii) greater than 2.71 V
questions.correctAnswer: $E_{cell} \approx 2.74\ \text{V}$. (i) Less than 2.71 V: Current flows from cathode to anode externally (galvanic cell). (ii) Greater than 2.71 V: Current flows from anode to cathode externally (electrolytic cell).
questions.solution:
Reaction Quotient Q:
$$Q = \frac{[Mg^{2+}][Cu]}{[Mg][Cu^{2+}]} = \frac{(0.001)(1)}{(1)(0.01)} = 0.1$$
(Concentrations of pure solids Mg and Cu are taken as 1)

Using Nernst Equation (n = 2 for the transfer of 2 electrons):
$$E_{cell} = E^\circ_{cell} - \frac{0.0591}{n}\log Q$$
$$E_{cell} = 2.71 - \frac{0.0591}{2}\log(0.1)$$
$$E_{cell} = 2.71 - \frac{0.0591}{2} \times (-1)$$
$$E_{cell} = 2.71 + 0.02955$$
$$E_{cell} \approx 2.74\ \text{V}$$

Direction of Current Flow:
(i) External potential < 2.71 V (< $E_{cell}$): The cell acts as a galvanic cell. Current flows from the cathode to the anode through the external circuit (conventional current flows from Cu electrode (cathode) to Mg electrode (anode) externally).
(ii) External potential > 2.71 V (> $E_{cell}$): The cell acts as an electrolytic cell (electrolysis occurs). Current flows from the anode to the cathode through the external circuit (the direction is reversed).

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) A steady current of 2 amperes was passed through two electrolytic cells X and Y connected in series containing electrolytes FeSO₄ and ZnSO₄ until 2.8 g of Fe deposited at the cathode of cell X. How long did the current flow? Calculate the mass of Zn deposited at the cathode of cell Y.

$(Molar\ mass: Fe = 56\ g\ mol^{-1},\ Zn = 65.3\ g\ mol^{-1},\ 1\ F = 96500\ C\ mol^{-1})$

(b) In the plot of molar conductivity $(\Lambda_m)$ vs square root of concentration $(c^{1/2})$, curves are obtained for two electrolytes A and B. Identify A and B as strong or weak electrolyte and explain. [Curve A shows a gentle decrease (nearly linear); Curve B shows a steep, non-linear increase as concentration decreases to zero]
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (a) Time = 4825 s; Mass of Zn = 3.265 g. (b) A = Strong electrolyte; B = Weak electrolyte.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) At cathode of Cell X:
$$Fe^{2+}(aq) + 2e^- \longrightarrow Fe(s)$$
Charge required to deposit 56 g of Fe = $96500 \times 2 = 193000$ C
Charge required to deposit 2.8 g of Fe:
$$Q = \frac{193000 \times 2.8}{56} = 9650\ \text{C}$$
Time for which current flowed:
$$Q = I \times t \implies t = \frac{Q}{I} = \frac{9650}{2} = 4825\ \text{s}$$

Mass of Zn deposited at cathode of Cell Y (using Faraday's Second Law):
$$\frac{W_1}{W_2} = \frac{E_1}{E_2} = \frac{\text{Equivalent weight of Fe}}{\text{Equivalent weight of Zn}}$$
$$\frac{2.8}{W_2} = \frac{56/2}{65.3/2} = \frac{56}{65.3}$$
$$W_2 = \frac{2.8 \times 65.3}{56} = 3.265\ \text{g}$$

(b) Identification of Electrolytes A and B:
- Electrolyte A (gentle, nearly linear decrease of $\Lambda_m$ with $c^{1/2}$, can be extrapolated to zero concentration) = Strong Electrolyte. For strong electrolytes, $\Lambda_m$ can be obtained by extrapolation to $c \to 0$ to get $\Lambda^\circ_m$.
- Electrolyte B (steep, non-linear increase of $\Lambda_m$ as concentration decreases, cannot be extrapolated) = Weak Electrolyte. For weak electrolytes, $\Lambda_m$ increases steeply on dilution (due to increased dissociation). Therefore, $\Lambda^\circ_m$ cannot be obtained by extrapolation for weak electrolytes.

questions.question:
(a) How do you convert the following:
(i) Phenol to Anisole
(ii) Ethanol to Propan-2-ol

(b) Write the mechanism of the following reaction:
$$C_2H_5OH \xrightarrow{H_2SO_4,\ 443\ K} CH_2 = CH_2 + H_2O$$

(c) Why does phenol undergo electrophilic substitution more easily than benzene?
questions.correctAnswer: (a)(i) Phenol → Sodium phenoxide (NaOH) → Anisole (CH₃Br, Williamson synthesis). (a)(ii) Ethanol → Acetaldehyde (PCC) → Propan-2-ol (CH₃MgBr, then H₂O). (b) Three-step mechanism: protonation, carbocation formation, deprotonation. (c) –OH activates ring by resonance, increasing electron density at ortho and para positions.
questions.solution:
(a)(i) Phenol to Anisole — Williamson Synthesis:
$$\underset{\text{Phenol}}{C_6H_5OH} \xrightarrow{NaOH} \underset{\text{Sodium phenoxide}}{C_6H_5O^-Na^+} \xrightarrow{CH_3Br} \underset{\textbf{Anisole}}{C_6H_5OCH_3}$$

(a)(ii) Ethanol to Propan-2-ol:
Step 1: Oxidise ethanol to acetaldehyde using PCC:
$$CH_3CH_2OH \xrightarrow{PCC} CH_3CHO$$
Step 2: React acetaldehyde with methylmagnesium bromide (Grignard reagent), then hydrolyse:
$$CH_3CHO + CH_3MgBr \longrightarrow CH_3CH(CH_3) - OMgBr \xrightarrow{H_2O} \underset{\textbf{Propan-2-ol}}{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3}$$

(b) Mechanism: Dehydration of Ethanol to Ethene:
Step 1 — Formation of protonated alcohol (Fast): Ethanol is protonated by $H_2SO_4$ to form a good leaving group ($H_2O$).
Step 2 — Formation of Carbocation (Slow, Rate-determining): The protonated ethanol loses water to form an ethyl carbocation.
Step 3 — Formation of Ethene (Fast): A proton is lost from the adjacent carbon, forming ethene and regenerating the acid catalyst.

(c) The $-OH$ group attached to the benzene ring in phenol is an activating group. Due to resonance, the lone pair on oxygen delocalises into the ring, increasing the electron density at the ortho and para positions. This makes the ring more nucleophilic and thus more susceptible to attack by electrophiles. Hence, phenol undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution more easily and faster than benzene.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a)(i) Account for: o-nitrophenol is more steam volatile than p-nitrophenol.

(a)(ii) Account for: t-butyl chloride on heating with sodium methoxide gives 2-methylpropene instead of t-butyl methyl ether.

(b) Write the reaction involved in the following:
(i) Reimer-Tiemann reaction
(ii) Friedel-Crafts Alkylation of Phenol

(c) Give a simple chemical test to distinguish between Ethanol and Phenol.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (a)(i) o-Nitrophenol has intramolecular H-bonding (more volatile); p-Nitrophenol has intermolecular H-bonding (less volatile). (a)(ii) Sodium methoxide is a strong base; E2 elimination predominates over SN2 with tertiary halide. (b)(i) Phenol + CHCl₃/NaOH → Salicylaldehyde. (b)(ii) Phenol + CH₃Cl/AlCl₃ → o-Cresol + p-Cresol. (c) Iodoform test: Ethanol gives yellow precipitate of CHI₃; Phenol does not.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a)(i) o-Nitrophenol vs p-Nitrophenol — Steam Volatility:
- o-Nitrophenol forms intramolecular hydrogen bonding (between –OH and –NO₂ within the same molecule). This prevents association between molecules, making it volatile (lower boiling point).
- p-Nitrophenol forms intermolecular hydrogen bonding (between –OH of one molecule and –NO₂ of another). This causes association between molecules, making it less volatile (higher boiling point).
Therefore, o-nitrophenol is more steam volatile than p-nitrophenol.

(a)(ii) t-Butyl chloride with sodium methoxide gives 2-methylpropene:
$$(CH_3)_3C-Cl + CH_3ONa^- \longrightarrow CH_2 = C(CH_3)_2 + CH_3OH + NaCl$$
Reason: Sodium methoxide ($CH_3O^-Na^+$) is a strong base. With a tertiary halide like t-butyl chloride, elimination reaction (E2) predominates over substitution ($S_N2$) because the tertiary carbon is sterically hindered ($S_N2$ is disfavoured) and the strong base abstracts a β-hydrogen, leading to elimination to form the alkene.

(b)(i) Reimer-Tiemann Reaction:
$$\underset{\text{Phenol}}{C_6H_5OH} \xrightarrow{CHCl_3 + \text{aq. NaOH}} \underset{\textbf{Salicylaldehyde}}{\text{o-HOC}_6H_4CHO}$$
Phenol reacts with chloroform in the presence of aqueous NaOH to give ortho-hydroxy benzaldehyde (salicylaldehyde) as the major product.

(b)(ii) Friedel-Crafts Alkylation of Phenol:
$$\underset{\text{Phenol}}{C_6H_5OH} \xrightarrow{CH_3Cl,\ \text{Anh. AlCl}_3} \underset{\text{o-Cresol}}{o\text{-}CH_3C_6H_4OH} + \underset{\text{p-Cresol}}{p\text{-}CH_3C_6H_4OH}$$

(c) Chemical Test to Distinguish Ethanol and Phenol — Iodoform Test:
Ethanol gives a positive iodoform test:
$$C_2H_5OH \xrightarrow{I_2/NaOH} CHI_3 \downarrow + HCOONa$$
A yellow precipitate of iodoform ($CHI_3$) is formed.
Phenol does not give iodoform test:
$$C_6H_5OH \xrightarrow{I_2/NaOH} \text{No yellow precipitate}$$
Observation: Ethanol gives a yellow precipitate (iodoform); phenol does not.

questions.question:
(a) Give reasons for the following:
(i) Sulphur in vapour state shows paramagnetic behaviour.
(ii) N–N bond is weaker than P–P bond.
(iii) Ozone is thermodynamically less stable than oxygen.

(b) Write the name of gas released when Cu is added to:
(i) dilute HNO₃
(ii) conc. HNO₃
questions.correctAnswer: (a)(i) S₂ in vapour state has two unpaired electrons in π* orbitals, making it paramagnetic. (a)(ii) N–N is weaker than P–P due to lone pair–lone pair repulsion in N. (a)(iii) Decomposition of ozone is exothermic with increase in entropy, so ΔG < 0 (spontaneous). (b)(i) Nitric oxide (NO). (b)(ii) Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂).
questions.solution:
(a)(i) Sulphur in Vapour State is Paramagnetic: Sulphur in vapour state exists as $S_2$ molecules, which are analogous to $O_2$. Like oxygen, $S_2$ has two unpaired electrons in the π* (pi-antibonding) molecular orbitals (following Hund's rule). The presence of unpaired electrons makes $S_2$ paramagnetic.

(a)(ii) N–N bond is weaker than P–P bond: Due to the very small atomic size of nitrogen, the non-bonding lone pairs on adjacent nitrogen atoms experience strong interelectronic repulsion (lone pair – lone pair repulsion). This repulsion weakens the N–N single bond. In contrast, phosphorus has a larger atomic size, so the lone pairs are farther apart and repulsion is much less. Therefore, P–P single bond is stronger than N–N single bond.

(a)(iii) Ozone is thermodynamically less stable than oxygen: The decomposition of ozone into oxygen:
$$2O_3(g) \longrightarrow 3O_2(g)$$
This reaction results in liberation of heat ($\Delta H < 0$, exothermic) and increase in entropy ($\Delta S > 0$, more moles of gas). Together, these give a large negative Gibbs energy change ($\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S < 0$), meaning the decomposition is spontaneous. Hence, ozone is thermodynamically less stable than oxygen.

(b)(i) Cu + dilute HNO₃ → Nitric oxide (NO):
$$3Cu + 8HNO_3\ (\text{dil.}) \longrightarrow 3Cu(NO_3)_2 + 2NO\uparrow + 4H_2O$$
Gas released: Nitric oxide (NO)

(b)(ii) Cu + conc. HNO₃ → Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂):
$$Cu + 4HNO_3\ (\text{conc.}) \longrightarrow Cu(NO_3)_2 + 2NO_2\uparrow + 2H_2O$$
Gas released: Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)

questions.question:
(a) Write the cell reaction and calculate the e.m.f. of the following cell at 298 K:

$$\text{Sn}(s)\ |\ \text{Sn}^{2+}(0.004\ M)\ \|\ \text{H}^+(0.020\ M)\ |\ \text{H}_2(g)(1\ \text{bar})\ |\ \text{Pt}(s)$$

Given: $E°_{\text{Sn}^{2+}/\text{Sn}} = -0.14\ \text{V}$

(b) Give reasons:

(i) On the basis of E° values, O₂ gas should be liberated at anode but it is Cl₂ gas which is liberated in the electrolysis of aqueous NaCl.

(ii) Conductivity of CH₃COOH decreases on dilution.
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) $E_{\text{cell}} = 0.111\ \text{V}$
(b)(i) Overvoltage for O₂ and high Cl⁻ concentration favour Cl₂ evolution.
(b)(ii) Number of ions per unit volume decreases on dilution.
questions.solution:
(a) Cell Reactions:
At anode (oxidation):
$$\text{Sn}(s) \longrightarrow \text{Sn}^{2+}(aq) + 2e^-$$
At cathode (reduction):
$$2\text{H}^+(aq) + 2e^- \longrightarrow \text{H}_2(g)$$
Overall redox reaction:
$$\text{Sn}(s) + 2\text{H}^+(aq) \longrightarrow \text{Sn}^{2+}(aq) + \text{H}_2(g)$$

Standard EMF:
$$E°_{\text{cell}} = E°_{\text{cathode}} - E°_{\text{anode}} = 0.00 - (-0.14) = +0.14\ \text{V}$$

Applying Nernst Equation (n = 2):
$$E = E°_{\text{cell}} - \frac{0.0591}{n}\log\frac{[\text{Sn}^{2+}] \times P_{\text{H}_2}}{[\text{H}^+]^2}$$
$$E = 0.14 - \frac{0.0591}{2}\log\frac{0.004 \times 1}{(0.020)^2}$$
$$E = 0.14 - 0.02955 \times \log\frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{4 \times 10^{-4}}$$
$$E = 0.14 - 0.02955 \times \log 10$$
$$E = 0.14 - 0.02955 \times 1$$
$$E_{\text{cell}} = 0.111\ \text{V}$$

(b)(i) Theoretically, based on standard reduction potential values:
$$E°_{\text{Cl}_2/\text{Cl}^-} = +1.36\ \text{V} \quad \text{and} \quad E°_{\text{O}_2/\text{H}_2\text{O}} = +1.23\ \text{V}$$
Since water has a lower reduction potential, it should be oxidised preferentially at the anode, liberating O₂. However, in the electrolysis of concentrated aqueous NaCl, Cl₂ is liberated due to:
1. Overvoltage (overpotential): Oxidation of water to O₂ requires a significantly higher overvoltage than predicted by thermodynamics.
2. High concentration of Cl⁻ ions: In concentrated NaCl solution, Cl⁻ ions are present in large numbers at the anode surface, making their discharge kinetically preferred.

(b)(ii) Conductivity (κ, specific conductance) is defined as the conductance of a solution of 1 cm³ volume. It depends on the number of ions per unit volume. When acetic acid (a weak electrolyte) is diluted:
- Although the degree of dissociation increases (more molecules ionise)
- The number of ions per unit volume (concentration) decreases significantly.
The decrease in ion concentration per unit volume outweighs the increase in degree of dissociation. Therefore, the conductivity (κ) decreases on dilution.
(Note: Molar conductivity increases on dilution, but conductivity decreases.)

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) For the reaction:
$$2\text{AgCl}(s) + \text{H}_2(g)(1\ \text{atm}) \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}(s) + 2\text{H}^+(0.1\ M) + 2\text{Cl}^-(0.1\ M)$$
$$\Delta G° = -43600\ \text{J at } 25°\text{C}$$
Calculate the e.m.f. of the cell. [log 10⁻ⁿ = –n]

(b) Define fuel cell and write its two advantages.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a) $E_{\text{cell}} = 0.3482\ \text{V}$
(b) Fuel cell: electrochemical cell converting chemical energy of fuel directly to electrical energy; Advantages: high efficiency (~60–70%), no polluting by-products.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) Finding E°cell from ΔG°:
$$\Delta G° = -nFE°$$
$$-43600 = -2 \times 96500 \times E°$$
$$E° = \frac{43600}{2 \times 96500} = 0.23\ \text{V}$$

Applying Nernst Equation (n = 2):
$$E = E°_{\text{cell}} - \frac{0.0591}{2}\log\frac{[\text{H}^+]^2[\text{Cl}^-]^2}{P_{\text{H}_2}}$$
$$E = 0.23 - \frac{0.0591}{2}\log\frac{(0.1)^2 \times (0.1)^2}{1}$$
$$E = 0.23 - 0.02955 \times \log(0.1)^4$$
$$E = 0.23 - 0.02955 \times \log(10^{-4})$$
$$E = 0.23 - 0.02955 \times (-4)$$
$$E = 0.23 + 0.1182$$
$$E_{\text{cell}} = 0.3482\ \text{V}$$

(b) Definition: A fuel cell is an electrochemical cell (voltaic/galvanic cell) in which the chemical energy from the combustion of fuels (like H₂, CH₄, methanol) is directly converted into electrical energy. The reactants (fuel and oxidant) are continuously supplied to the electrodes during operation.

Example — Hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell:
- At anode: $\text{H}_2 + 2\text{OH}^- \rightarrow 2\text{H}_2\text{O} + 2e^-$
- At cathode: $\frac{1}{2}\text{O}_2 + \text{H}_2\text{O} + 2e^- \rightarrow 2\text{OH}^-$

Advantages:
1. Fuel cells operate with an efficiency of 60–70%, much higher than conventional heat engines (~40%).
2. There are no objectionable or polluting by-products — hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells produce only water. Therefore, they are a pollution-free source of energy.

questions.question:
(a) Write the reactions involved in the following:

(i) Hofmann bromamide degradation reaction

(ii) Diazotisation

(iii) Gabriel phthalamide synthesis

(b) Give reasons:

(i) (CH₃)₂NH is more basic than (CH₃)₃N in an aqueous solution.

(ii) Aromatic diazonium salts are more stable than aliphatic diazonium salts.
questions.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Amide + Br₂/NaOH → primary amine (one carbon less)
(a)(ii) Ar–NH₂ + NaNO₂/HCl at 0–5°C → Ar–N₂⁺Cl⁻
(a)(iii) Phthalimide + KOH → K-salt + RX → N-alkyl phthalimide → hydrolysis → R–NH₂
(b)(i) Better solvation of (CH₃)₂NH₂⁺ (2 N–H bonds) vs. (CH₃)₃NH⁺ (1 N–H bond)
(b)(ii) Positive charge delocalized into the benzene ring in aromatic diazonium salts
questions.solution:
(a)(i) Hofmann bromamide degradation reaction:
$$\text{R–CH}_2\text{–C(=O)–NH}_2 + 4\text{NaOH} + \text{Br}_2 \longrightarrow \text{R–CH}_2\text{–NH}_2 + \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + 2\text{NaBr} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}$$
Example:
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{C(=O)NH}_2 + 4\text{NaOH} + \text{Br}_2 \longrightarrow \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{NH}_2 + \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + 2\text{NaBr} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}$$
(Propionamide → Ethylamine: the amine product has one carbon less than the amide)

(a)(ii) Diazotisation:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 + \text{NaNO}_2 + \text{HCl} \xrightarrow{0\text{–}5°\text{C}} \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\overset{+}{\text{N}} \equiv \text{N}\ \text{Cl}^- + \text{NaCl} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$

(a)(iii) Gabriel phthalamide synthesis:
Step 1: Phthalimide + KOH → Potassium phthalimide + H₂O
Step 2: Potassium phthalimide + R–X → N-alkyl phthalimide + KX
Step 3: N-alkyl phthalimide + H⁺/H₂O (hydrolysis) → R–NH₂ + phthalic acid (o-HOOC–C₆H₄–COOH)

(b)(i) In aqueous solution, basicity of amines depends on:
1. +I (inductive) effect of alkyl groups — increases electron density on N
2. Solvation of the conjugate acid (ammonium ion) — more H atoms on N⁺ → better solvation → more stable → stronger base

For $(CH_3)_3N$ (tertiary amine): The trimethylammonium ion $(CH_3)_3\text{NH}^+$ has only 1 N–H bond for hydrogen bonding with water → poor solvation → less stable → weaker base in water.
For $(CH_3)_2NH$ (secondary amine): The dimethylammonium ion $(CH_3)_2\text{NH}_2^+$ has 2 N–H bonds → better solvation by water molecules → more stable → stronger base in water.
Therefore, $(CH_3)_2NH$ is more basic than $(CH_3)_3N$ in aqueous solution.

(b)(ii) In aromatic diazonium salts (e.g., $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\overset{+}{\text{N}}\equiv\text{N}$), the positive charge on the diazonium group is delocalized over the benzene ring through resonance. This dispersal/delocalization of the positive charge stabilizes the aromatic diazonium salt.
In aliphatic diazonium salts, the alkyl group cannot participate in resonance, so charge dispersal is not possible → they are highly unstable and decompose immediately.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Write the structures of the main products of the following reactions:

(i) $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 \xrightarrow{(\text{CH}_3\text{CO})_2\text{O},\ \text{Pyridine}} ?$

(ii) $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{SO}_2\text{Cl} \xrightarrow{(\text{CH}_3)_2\text{NH}} ?$

(iii) $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\overset{+}{\text{N}}_2\text{Cl}^- \xrightarrow{\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH}} ?$

(b) Give a simple chemical test to distinguish between Aniline and N,N-dimethylaniline.

(c) Arrange the following in the increasing order of their pKb values:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2,\quad \text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2,\quad \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NHCH}_3$$
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Acetanilide (C₆H₅–NH–CO–CH₃)
(a)(ii) N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (C₆H₅SO₂–N(CH₃)₂)
(a)(iii) Benzene (C₆H₆)
(b) Carbylamine test: aniline gives foul-smelling isocyanide; N,N-dimethylaniline does not.
(c) C₂H₅NH₂ < C₆H₅NH₂ < C₆H₅NHCH₃ (increasing pKb)
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a)(i) Aniline reacts with acetic anhydride in the presence of pyridine (as a base) to undergo acetylation (acylation), giving acetanilide:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 + (\text{CH}_3\text{CO})_2\text{O} \xrightarrow{\text{Pyridine}} \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{–NH–C(=O)–CH}_3 + \text{CH}_3\text{COOH}$$
Product: Acetanilide (N-phenylethanamide)

(a)(ii) Benzenesulfonyl chloride reacts with dimethylamine (a secondary amine) to give a sulfonamide:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{SO}_2\text{Cl} + (\text{CH}_3)_2\text{NH} \longrightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{SO}_2\text{–N(CH}_3)_2 + \text{HCl}$$
Product: N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide

(a)(iii) When benzene diazonium chloride reacts with ethanol, reduction of the diazonium salt occurs, replacing the diazonium group (–N₂⁺) with a hydrogen atom, and ethanol is oxidised to acetaldehyde:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\overset{+}{\text{N}}_2\text{Cl}^- + \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} \longrightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_6 + \text{N}_2 + \text{CH}_3\text{CHO} + \text{HCl}$$
Product: Benzene

(b) Carbylamine (isocyanide) test:
- Aniline ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2$, primary amine): Reacts with CHCl₃ and KOH to give phenyl isocyanide (foul-smelling compound):
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 + \text{CHCl}_3 + 3\text{KOH} \longrightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\overset{+}{\text{N}} \equiv \overset{-}{\text{C}} + 3\text{KCl} + 3\text{H}_2\text{O}$$
The formation of the foul-smelling isocyanide confirms the presence of a primary amine.
- N,N-dimethylaniline ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{N(CH}_3)_2$, tertiary amine): Does not react with CHCl₃ and KOH → no foul smell.
Conclusion: The compound that gives a foul-smelling product with CHCl₃/KOH is aniline.

(c) Increasing order of pKb (decreasing basicity):
- $\text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2$ (ethylamine, aliphatic amine): Most basic due to +I effect of ethyl group → lowest pKb
- $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2$ (aniline): Lone pair on N is delocalized into the benzene ring (–M effect) → less basic → higher pKb
- $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NHCH}_3$ (N-methylaniline): Still delocalized into ring, steric factors make N less basic → highest pKb

Order: $\text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 < \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 < \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NHCH}_3$ (increasing pKb)

questions.question:
Give reasons:

(i) H₃PO₃ undergoes disproportionation reaction but H₃PO₄ does not.

(ii) When Cl₂ reacts with excess of F₂, ClF₃ is formed and not FCl₃.

(iii) Dioxygen is a gas while Sulphur is a solid at room temperature.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) P in H₃PO₃ is +3 (intermediate oxidation state, can disproportionate); P in H₃PO₄ is +5 (highest oxidation state, cannot be oxidised further).
(ii) F cannot show positive oxidation states; Cl can show +3 in ClF₃.
(iii) O₂ is a diatomic molecule with weak van der Waals forces; S forms S₈ rings with stronger intermolecular forces.
questions.solution:
(i) In $\text{H}_3\text{PO}_3$ (phosphorous acid): Oxidation state of P = +3. Since P is in an intermediate oxidation state (+3), it can undergo both oxidation (to +5) and reduction (to 0 or –3). Therefore, H₃PO₃ can disproportionate:
$$4\text{H}_3\text{PO}_3 \longrightarrow 3\text{H}_3\text{PO}_4 + \text{PH}_3$$

In $\text{H}_3\text{PO}_4$ (phosphoric acid): Oxidation state of P = +5. This is the highest oxidation state of phosphorus. It can only undergo reduction (act as oxidising agent) but cannot be oxidised further. Therefore, H₃PO₄ cannot undergo disproportionation.

(ii) Fluorine is the most electronegative element and can exist only in the –1 oxidation state. It cannot show positive oxidation states.
Chlorine, being less electronegative, can show positive oxidation states when bonded to the more electronegative fluorine.
In $\text{ClF}_3$: Cl has oxidation state = +3 (which is possible for Cl).
If $\text{FCl}_3$ were formed, F would need to be in +3 oxidation state — which is impossible for fluorine due to its high electronegativity and absence of d-orbitals.
Therefore, only $\text{ClF}_3$ is formed, not $\text{FCl}_3$.

(iii) O₂ (Dioxygen): Oxygen forms a diatomic molecule ($\text{O}=\text{O}$) with a $p\pi – p\pi$ double bond (due to small size and availability of p-orbitals for lateral overlap). The intermolecular forces in O₂ are very weak van der Waals forces. Therefore, dioxygen is a gas at room temperature with very low boiling point.
Sulphur: Due to its larger atomic size, sulphur cannot form $p\pi – p\pi$ bonds effectively. Instead, it forms puckered S₈ rings held together by stronger van der Waals forces due to the larger molecular size and higher molecular mass of S₈. These stronger intermolecular forces keep sulphur as a solid at room temperature.

questions.question:
(a) Account for the following:
(i) Transition metals show variable oxidation states.
(ii) Zn, Cd and Hg are soft metals.
(iii) $E°$ value for the $Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}$ couple is highly positive (+1.57 V) as compared to $Cr^{3+}/Cr^{2+}$.

(b) Write one similarity and one difference between the chemistry of lanthanoid and actinoid elements.
questions.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Both ns and (n–1)d electrons participate in bonding due to small energy difference, giving variable oxidation states.
(a)(ii) Zn, Cd, Hg have completely filled d¹⁰ configuration, so no covalent bonding through d-orbitals, only weak metallic bonds exist.
(a)(iii) Mn²⁺ has d⁵ (half-filled) configuration which is extra stable, so Mn³⁺ readily reduces to Mn²⁺ giving high positive E°.
(b) Similarity: Both show mainly +3 oxidation state. Difference: Actinoids form oxo-cations (e.g., UO₂²⁺); lanthanoids do not.
questions.solution:
**(a)(i) Variable oxidation states in transition metals:**

In transition elements, both **ns** and **(n–1)d** electrons participate in bonding due to very little energy difference between them. When only ns electrons take part in bonding, they exhibit lower oxidation states. When both ns and (n–1)d electrons participate, they exhibit higher oxidation states. This leads to **variable oxidation states**.

**(a)(ii) Zn, Cd and Hg are soft metals:**

Transition elements are generally hard and have high melting and boiling points because they exhibit both **covalent and metallic bonding** due to partially filled d-orbitals. However, Group 12 elements (Zn, Cd, Hg) have **completely filled (n–1)d orbitals** ($d^{10}$ configuration), so they cannot exhibit covalent bonding through d-orbitals. Only weak metallic bonds exist, making them **soft metals** with low melting points.

**(a)(iii) $E°$ for $Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}$ is highly positive:**

$Mn^{2+}$ has a $d^5$ (half-filled) configuration, which is **extra stable** due to exchange energy. Therefore, $Mn^{3+}$ readily gets reduced to the stable $Mn^{2+}$, resulting in a **high positive $E°$** value for the $Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}$ couple.

In contrast, $Cr^{3+}$ ($d^3$, half-filled $t_{2g}$) is more stable than $Cr^{2+}$, so $Cr^{3+}$ does not easily reduce to $Cr^{2+}$, resulting in a **low $E°$** value.

**(b) Lanthanoids vs. Actinoids:**

**Similarity:**
- Both series of elements exhibit mainly **+3 oxidation state**.

**Difference:**

| Lanthanoids | Actinoids |
|---|---|
| Less tendency to form complexes | High tendency to form complexes |
| Do not form oxo-cations | Form oxo-cations, e.g., $UO_2^{2+}$, $TiO^{2+}$ |

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Following are the transition metal ions of 3d series:
$Ti^{4+}$, $V^{2+}$, $Mn^{3+}$, $Cr^{3+}$
(Atomic Numbers: Ti = 22, V = 23, Mn = 25, Cr = 24)

Answer the following:
(i) Which ion is most stable in an aqueous solution and why?
(ii) Which ion is a strong oxidising agent and why?
(iii) Which ion is colourless and why?

(b) Complete the following equations:
(i) $2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5S^{2-} \longrightarrow$
(ii) $KMnO_4 \xrightarrow{\text{heat}}$
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Cr³⁺ (d³, half-filled t₂g, extra stable)
(a)(ii) Mn³⁺ (readily reduced to stable Mn²⁺ d⁵ configuration)
(a)(iii) Ti⁴⁺ (d⁰ configuration, no d-d transitions possible)
(b)(i) $2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5S^{2-} \longrightarrow 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O + 5S$
(b)(ii) $2KMnO_4 \xrightarrow{\text{heat}} K_2MnO_4 + MnO_2 + O_2\uparrow$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**(a)(i) Most stable ion in aqueous solution:**

**$Cr^{3+}$** is the most stable ion in aqueous solution.

**Reason:** $Cr^{3+}$ has a $d^3$ configuration (half-filled $t_{2g}$ sub-level), which gives it extra stability. It has a small size and high charge density, making it strongly stabilized by hydration in aqueous solution.

**(a)(ii) Strong oxidising agent:**

**$Mn^{3+}$** is the strongest oxidising agent.

**Reason:** $Mn^{2+}$ ($d^5$, half-filled) is more stable than $Mn^{3+}$ ($d^4$). Therefore, $Mn^{3+}$ has a strong tendency to gain an electron and be reduced to the stable $Mn^{2+}$, making it a **strong oxidising agent**.

**(a)(iii) Colourless ion:**

**$Ti^{4+}$** is colourless.

**Reason:** $Ti^{4+}$ has a $d^0$ configuration (no $d$-electrons). Since colour in transition metal ions arises from **d–d transitions**, and $Ti^{4+}$ has no $d$-electrons available for excitation, it is **colourless**.

**(b) Completed equations:**

**(i)**
$$2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5S^{2-} \longrightarrow 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O + 5S$$

**(ii)**
$$2KMnO_4 \xrightarrow{\text{heat}} K_2MnO_4 + MnO_2 + O_2\uparrow$$

questions.question:
(a) A 10% solution (by mass) of sucrose in water has a freezing point of 269.15 K. Calculate the freezing point of 10% glucose in water if the freezing point of pure water is 273.15 K.

Given:
- Molar mass of sucrose = 342 g mol⁻¹
- Molar mass of glucose = 180 g mol⁻¹

(b) Define the following terms:
(i) Molality (m)
(ii) Abnormal molar mass
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) Freezing point of 10% glucose solution = 265.45 K
(b)(i) Molality = moles of solute per kg of solvent.
(b)(ii) Abnormal molar mass is the experimentally determined molar mass that differs from the theoretical value due to association or dissociation of solute in solution.
questions.solution:
**(a) Freezing point of 10% glucose solution:**

**For sucrose solution (10% by mass):**
- Mass of sucrose $(w) = 10$ g
- Mass of water = 90 g
- Molar mass of sucrose = 342 g/mol

Molality of sucrose solution:
$$m_{sucrose} = \frac{10}{342} \times \frac{1000}{90} = \frac{10000}{30780} = 0.325 \text{ mol/kg}$$

Depression in freezing point:
$$\Delta t_f = 273.15 - 269.15 = 4 \text{ K}$$

Finding $K_f$:
$$K_f = \frac{\Delta t_f}{m} = \frac{4}{0.325} = 12.30 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$$

**For glucose solution (10% by mass):**
- Mass of glucose $(w) = 10$ g
- Mass of water = 90 g
- Molar mass of glucose = 180 g/mol

Molality of glucose solution:
$$m_{glucose} = \frac{10}{180} \times \frac{1000}{90} = 0.617 \text{ mol/kg}$$

Depression in freezing point:
$$\Delta t_f = K_f \times m_{glucose} = 12.30 \times 0.617 \approx 7.7 \text{ K}$$

Freezing point of glucose solution:
$$t_{f(\text{solution})} = 273.15 - 7.7 = 265.45 \text{ K}$$

**(b)(i) Molality (m):**

Molality is defined as the **number of moles of solute dissolved per kilogram (1000 g) of the solvent**.
$$m = \frac{\text{Moles of solute}}{\text{Mass of solvent in kg}}$$

**(b)(ii) Abnormal molar mass:**

When a substance undergoes **association or dissociation** in solution, the molar mass determined experimentally from colligative properties is **different from the theoretically expected (normal) value**. This experimentally determined molar mass is called the **abnormal molar mass**.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) 30 g of urea (M = 60 g mol⁻¹) is dissolved in 846 g of water. Calculate the vapour pressure of water for this solution if vapour pressure of pure water at 298 K is 23.8 mm Hg.

(b) Write two differences between ideal solutions and non-ideal solutions.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a) Vapour pressure of the solution = 23.54 mm Hg
(b) Ideal solutions obey Raoult's law and ΔH_mix = 0; non-ideal solutions do not obey Raoult's law and ΔH_mix ≠ 0.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**(a) Vapour pressure of the urea solution:**

Given:
- Mass of urea $(w_2) = 30$ g, $M_2 = 60$ g/mol
- Mass of water $(w_1) = 846$ g, $M_1 = 18$ g/mol
- $P° = 23.8$ mm Hg

Using Raoult's law:
$$\frac{P° - P_s}{P°} = x_2 = \frac{W_2/M_2}{W_2/M_2 + W_1/M_1}$$

$$\frac{23.8 - P_s}{23.8} = \frac{30/60}{30/60 + 846/18} = \frac{0.5}{0.5 + 47} = \frac{0.5}{47.5} = 0.01053$$

$$23.8 - P_s = 0.01053 \times 23.8 = 0.2506$$

$$P_s = 23.8 - 0.2506 \approx 23.54 \text{ mm Hg}$$

**(b) Differences between ideal and non-ideal solutions:**

| Ideal Solutions | Non-ideal Solutions |
|---|---|
| Obey Raoult's law at every range of concentration. | Do not obey Raoult's law. |
| Neither heat is absorbed nor evolved during dissolution ($\Delta H_{mix} = 0$). | Heat is either evolved (negative deviation) or absorbed (positive deviation) during dissolution ($\Delta H_{mix} \neq 0$). |

questions.question:
(a) Write the product(s) in the following reactions:

(i) Cyclohexanone $+ HCN \longrightarrow ?$

(ii) Sodium benzoate $+ NaOH \xrightarrow{CaO, \Delta} ?$

(iii) $CH_3-CH=CH-CN \xrightarrow{(a)\text{ DIBAL-H}} \xrightarrow{(b)H_2O} ?$

(b) Give simple chemical tests to distinguish between the following pairs of compounds:
(i) Butanal and Butan-2-one
(ii) Benzoic acid and Phenol
questions.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Cyclohexanone cyanohydrin (1-hydroxycyclohexane-1-carbonitrile)
(a)(ii) Benzene ($C_6H_6$) and $Na_2CO_3$
(a)(iii) But-2-enal (Crotonaldehyde, $CH_3-CH=CH-CHO$)
(b)(i) Tollen's reagent: Butanal gives silver mirror; Butan-2-one does not.
(b)(ii) FeCl₃ test: Phenol gives violet colouration; Benzoic acid gives buff-coloured precipitate.
questions.solution:
**(a) Products of the reactions:**

**(i) Cyclohexanone + HCN:**
Product: **Cyclohexanone cyanohydrin** (1-hydroxycyclohexane-1-carbonitrile)
HCN adds across the C=O bond of cyclohexanone; OH and CN groups attach to the same carbon.

**(ii) Sodium benzoate + NaOH $\xrightarrow{CaO, \Delta}$:**
$$C_6H_5COONa + NaOH \xrightarrow{CaO, \Delta} C_6H_6 + Na_2CO_3$$
Product: **Benzene** ($C_6H_6$) — decarboxylation reaction.

**(iii) $CH_3-CH=CH-CN \xrightarrow{(a)\text{ DIBAL-H}, (b)H_2O}$:**
$$CH_3-CH=CH-CN \xrightarrow{(a)\text{ DIBAL-H}} \xrightarrow{(b)H_2O} CH_3-CH=CH-CHO$$
Product: **But-2-enal** (Crotonaldehyde)
DIBAL-H reduces the nitrile (–CN) group to an aldehyde (–CHO).

**(b) Chemical tests to distinguish:**

**(i) Butanal and Butan-2-one — Tollen's reagent test:**
$$CH_3CH_2CH_2CHO + 2[Ag(NH_3)_2]^{\oplus} + 3OH^{\ominus} \longrightarrow CH_3CH_2CH_2COO^{\ominus} + 2Ag\downarrow + 4NH_3 + 2H_2O$$
$$CH_3COCH_2CH_3 \xrightarrow{\text{Tollens' Reagent}} \text{No silver mirror formed}$$

- **Butanal** (aldehyde): Gives **silver mirror** with Tollen's reagent ✓
- **Butan-2-one** (ketone): **No silver mirror** ✗

**(ii) Benzoic acid and Phenol — FeCl₃ test:**
$$C_6H_5OH + FeCl_3 \longrightarrow \textbf{Violet colouration}$$
$$3C_6H_5COOH + FeCl_3 \longrightarrow (C_6H_5COO)_3Fe + 3HCl \quad \text{(buff-coloured precipitate)}$$

- **Phenol:** Gives **violet/purple colouration** with FeCl₃ ✓
- **Benzoic acid:** Gives a **buff-coloured precipitate** (ferric benzoate) with FeCl₃ ✓

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Write the reactions involved in the following:
(i) Etard reaction
(ii) Stephen reduction

(b) How will you convert the following in not more than two steps:
(i) Benzoic acid to Benzaldehyde
(ii) Acetophenone to Benzoic acid
(iii) Ethanoic acid to 2-Hydroxyethanoic acid
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) Etard reaction: Toluene + CrO₂Cl₂ in CS₂ → chromium complex → (H₃O⁺) → Benzaldehyde
(a)(ii) Stephen reduction: R–C≡N + SnCl₂/HCl → R–CH=NH → (H₃O⁺) → R–CHO
(b)(i) Benzoic acid → (SOCl₂) → Benzoyl chloride → (H₂/Pd-BaSO₄) → Benzaldehyde
(b)(ii) Acetophenone → (I₂/NaOH) → Sodium benzoate → (H₃O⁺) → Benzoic acid
(b)(iii) Ethanoic acid → (X₂/P₄, then H₂O) → α-Haloacetic acid → (NaOH/acetone) → 2-Hydroxyethanoic acid
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**(a) Reactions involved:**

**(i) Etard reaction:**

Toluene is oxidized by chromyl chloride ($CrO_2Cl_2$) in $CS_2$ to give a chromium complex, which on hydrolysis gives benzaldehyde.

$$\underbrace{C_6H_5CH_3}_{\text{Toluene}} + CrO_2Cl_2 \xrightarrow{CS_2} \underbrace{C_6H_5CH(OCrOHCl_2)}_{\text{Chromium complex}} \xrightarrow{H_3O^+} \underbrace{C_6H_5CHO}_{\text{Benzaldehyde}}$$

**(ii) Stephen reduction:**

A nitrile (cyanide) is reduced by stannous chloride ($SnCl_2$) and HCl in anhydrous ether to give an aldimine salt, which on hydrolysis gives an aldehyde.

$$R-C\equiv N + SnCl_2 + HCl \longrightarrow R-CH=NH \xrightarrow{H_3O^+} R-CHO$$

**(b) Conversions:**

**(i) Benzoic acid to Benzaldehyde:**
$$\underbrace{C_6H_5COOH}_{\text{Benzoic acid}} \xrightarrow{SOCl_2} \underbrace{C_6H_5COCl}_{\text{Benzoyl chloride}} \xrightarrow{Pd/BaSO_4, H_2} \underbrace{C_6H_5CHO}_{\text{Benzaldehyde}}$$
Step 1: Reaction with $SOCl_2$ → Benzoyl chloride
Step 2: Rosenmund reduction with $H_2/Pd$-$BaSO_4$ → Benzaldehyde

**(ii) Acetophenone to Benzoic acid:**
$$\underbrace{C_6H_5COCH_3}_{\text{Acetophenone}} \xrightarrow{I_2/NaOH} \underbrace{C_6H_5COONa}_{\text{Sodium benzoate}} \xrightarrow{H_3O^{\oplus}} \underbrace{C_6H_5COOH}_{\text{Benzoic acid}}$$
Step 1: Iodoform reaction with $I_2$/NaOH → Sodium benzoate + CHI₃
Step 2: Acidification with $H_3O^+$ → Benzoic acid

**(iii) Ethanoic acid to 2-Hydroxyethanoic acid:**
$$\underbrace{CH_3-COOH}_{\text{Ethanoic acid}} \xrightarrow{X_2/P_4, \text{ then } H_2O} \underbrace{X-CH_2-COOH}_{\alpha\text{-Halocarboxylic acid}} \xrightarrow{NaOH/\text{acetone}} \underbrace{HO-CH_2-COOH}_{\text{2-Hydroxyethanoic acid}}$$
Step 1: Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky reaction with $X_2/P_4$ then $H_2O$ → $\alpha$-Haloacetic acid
Step 2: $S_N2$ reaction with NaOH in acetone → 2-Hydroxyethanoic acid (Glycolic acid)

questions.question:
(a) Calculate E° for the following reaction at 298 K:
$$2\text{Al(s)} + 3\text{Cu}^{2+}(0.01\text{ M}) \rightarrow 2\text{Al}^{3+}(0.01\text{ M}) + 3\text{Cu(s)}$$
Given: $E_{\text{cell}} = 1.98 \text{ V}$

(b) Using the E° values of A and B, predict which is better for coating the surface of iron [$E^\circ(\text{Fe}^{2+}/\text{Fe}) = -0.44\text{ V}$] to prevent corrosion and why?
Given: $E^\circ(\text{A}^{2+}/\text{A}) = -2.37 \text{ V}$; $E^\circ(\text{B}^{2+}/\text{B}) = -0.14 \text{ V}$
questions.correctAnswer: (a) $E^\circ_{\text{cell}} \approx 2.00 \text{ V}$ (b) Metal A is better for coating iron to prevent corrosion as it acts as a sacrificial anode.
questions.solution:
(a) Using the Nernst equation: E_cell = E°_cell - (0.0591/n) × log Q. For 2Al + 3Cu²⁺ → 2Al³⁺ + 3Cu, n = 6. Q = [Al³⁺]²/[Cu²⁺]³ = (0.01)²/(0.01)³ = 10⁻⁴/10⁻⁶ = 100. So: 1.98 = E°_cell - (0.0591/6) × log 100 = E°_cell - (0.0591/6) × 2 = E°_cell - 0.0197. E°_cell = 1.98 + 0.0197 = 1.9997 V ≈ 2.00 V.

(b) To prevent corrosion of iron by coating, the coating metal should act as a sacrificial anode (cathodic protection) — i.e., the coating metal should be more reactive (more easily oxidised) than iron. E°(Fe²⁺/Fe) = -0.44 V. E°(A²⁺/A) = -2.37 V → more negative → more easily oxidised → more reactive than Fe → acts as sacrificial anode. E°(B²⁺/B) = -0.14 V → less negative than Fe → less reactive → if coating is broken, Fe being more reactive would corrode faster. Therefore, Metal A provides better protection by acting as a sacrificial anode, oxidising preferentially to protect the iron underneath.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) The conductivity of 0.001 mol L⁻¹ solution of CH₃COOH is $3.905 \times 10^{-5}$ S cm⁻¹. Calculate its molar conductivity and degree of dissociation (α).
Given: $\lambda^\circ(\text{H}^+) = 349.6$ S cm² mol⁻¹ and $\lambda^\circ(\text{CH}_3\text{COO}^-) = 40.9$ S cm² mol⁻¹

(b) Define electrochemical cell. What happens if external potential applied becomes greater than $E^\circ_{\text{cell}}$ of an electrochemical cell?
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (a) λ_m = 39.05 S cm² mol⁻¹; α = 0.1 (10% dissociation). (b) An electrochemical cell converts chemical energy into electrical energy. If external potential exceeds E°_cell, the cell reaction reverses and the cell acts as an electrolytic cell.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) Given: C = 0.001 mol L⁻¹, κ = 3.905 × 10⁻⁵ S cm⁻¹. Molar conductivity: λ_m = (κ × 1000) / C = (3.905 × 10⁻⁵ × 1000) / 0.001 = 39.05 S cm² mol⁻¹. Molar conductivity at infinite dilution: CH₃COOH → CH₃COO⁻ + H⁺. λ°_m(CH₃COOH) = λ°(CH₃COO⁻) + λ°(H⁺) = 40.9 + 349.6 = 390.5 S cm² mol⁻¹. Degree of dissociation: α = λ_m / λ°_m = 39.05 / 390.5 = 0.1 (i.e., 10% dissociation).

(b) An electrochemical cell is a device that converts chemical energy into electrical energy (or vice versa). It generates electricity from the energy released during a spontaneous redox reaction (in a galvanic/voltaic cell) or uses electrical energy to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction (in an electrolytic cell). When the external potential applied to an electrochemical cell exceeds the E°_cell of the cell, the direction of the cell reaction is reversed. The galvanic cell is converted into an electrolytic cell, and electrolysis occurs — the non-spontaneous reverse reaction is forced to occur. This principle is the basis of recharging batteries and electrolytic refining of metals.

questions.question:
(a) Account for the following:
(i) Mn shows the highest oxidation state of +7 with oxygen but with fluorine it shows the highest oxidation state of +4.
(ii) Cr²⁺ is a strong reducing agent.
(iii) Cu²⁺ salts are coloured while Zn²⁺ salts are white.

(b) Complete the following equations:
(i) $2\text{MnO}_2 + 4\text{KOH} + \text{O}_2 \xrightarrow{\Delta}$
(ii) $\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6\text{I}^- \rightarrow$
questions.correctAnswer: (a)(i) Mn forms pπ–dπ bonds with O allowing +7 state; F has no d-orbitals so cannot form pπ–dπ bonds, limiting Mn to +4. (ii) Cr³⁺ (3d³) is more stable than Cr²⁺ (3d⁴), so Cr²⁺ readily loses an electron, acting as a strong reducing agent. (iii) Zn²⁺ has completely filled 3d¹⁰, no d–d transitions possible; Cu²⁺ has 3d⁹ with one vacancy, d–d transitions absorb visible light making it coloured. (b)(i) 2K₂MnO₄ + 2H₂O (ii) 2Cr³⁺ + 3I₂ + 7H₂O
questions.solution:
(a)(i) Manganese can form pπ–dπ bonds with oxygen (using the 2p orbitals of oxygen and 3d orbitals of Mn), which stabilise high oxidation states, allowing Mn to reach +7 (as in KMnO₄). Fluorine, being the most electronegative element and having no d-orbitals, cannot form pπ–dπ bonds. Therefore, with fluorine, Mn can only achieve the highest oxidation state of +4 (as in MnF₄).

(ii) The electronic configuration of Cr²⁺ is [Ar] 3d⁴ and that of Cr³⁺ is [Ar] 3d³. The 3d³ configuration of Cr³⁺ is relatively more stable (half-filled t₂g subshell in octahedral field). Due to the greater stability of the +3 oxidation state, Cr²⁺ has a strong tendency to lose one more electron and get oxidised to Cr³⁺. Therefore, Cr²⁺ acts as a strong reducing agent.

(iii) Zn²⁺: configuration [Ar] 3d¹⁰ — the d-subshell is completely filled. No d–d electronic transition is possible. Therefore, Zn²⁺ salts do not absorb visible light and appear white (colourless). Cu²⁺: configuration [Ar] 3d⁹ — the d-subshell is partially filled (one vacancy). d–d transitions are possible, absorbing visible light, making Cu²⁺ salts coloured (blue-green).

(b)(i) 2MnO₂ + 4KOH + O₂ → 2K₂MnO₄ + 2H₂O (MnO₂ is oxidised to potassium manganate).
(ii) Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6I⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 3I₂ + 7H₂O. Dichromate ion is a strong oxidizing agent in acidic medium, oxidising I⁻ to I₂ while Cr is reduced from +6 to +3.

alternativeQuestion.question:
The elements of the 3d transition series are: Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn.
Answer the following:
(i) Write the element which shows the maximum number of oxidation states. Give a reason.
(ii) Which element has the highest melting point?
(iii) Which element shows only +3 oxidation state?
(iv) Which element is a strong oxidizing agent in +3 oxidation state and why?
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (i) Mn shows maximum oxidation states (+2 to +7) due to 7 electrons (3d⁵4s²) available for bonding. (ii) Cr has the highest melting point due to 6 unpaired electrons forming strong metallic bonds. (iii) Sc shows only +3 oxidation state. (iv) Mn³⁺ is a strong oxidizing agent because Mn²⁺ (3d⁵) has extra-stable half-filled configuration.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Manganese (Mn) shows the maximum number of oxidation states (+2, +3, +4, +5, +6, +7). Mn has the electronic configuration [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s². It has a total of 7 electrons (5 in 3d + 2 in 4s) that can participate in bonding/oxidation. Since it is at the middle of the 3d series, it can utilise all these electrons in various oxidation states from +2 to +7.

(ii) Chromium (Cr) has the highest melting point among 3d transition elements. Cr has the configuration [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹, giving 6 unpaired electrons (5 from 3d + 1 from 4s) that participate in the formation of strong metallic bonds. The greater the number of unpaired electrons contributing to metallic bonding, the higher the melting point.

(iii) Scandium (Sc) shows only the +3 oxidation state. Sc has the configuration [Ar] 3d¹ 4s². It loses all 3 electrons (1 from 3d and 2 from 4s) to achieve the stable noble gas configuration of Ar. The +3 state is the only oxidation state exhibited by Sc.

(iv) Mn (Manganese) is a strong oxidizing agent in the +3 oxidation state. Mn³⁺ (3d⁴) readily gets reduced to Mn²⁺ (3d⁵) because the 3d⁵ configuration is an extra-stable half-filled configuration. This tendency to gain stability by acquiring the half-filled d⁵ configuration drives Mn³⁺ to act as a strong oxidizing agent.

questions.question:
(a) Write the structures of A and B in the following reactions:

(i) $\text{CH}_3\text{COCl} \xrightarrow{\text{H}_2,\; \text{Pd-BaSO}_4} \text{A} \xrightarrow{\text{H}_2\text{N-OH}} \text{B}$

(ii) $\text{CH}_3\text{MgBr} \xrightarrow{\text{1. CO}_2,\; \text{2. H}_3\text{O}^+} \text{A} \xrightarrow{\text{PCl}_5} \text{B}$

(b) Distinguish between:
(i) C₆H₅–COCH₃ and C₆H₅–CHO
(ii) CH₃COOH and HCOOH

(c) Arrange the following in the increasing order of their boiling points:
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CHO}, \quad \text{CH}_3\text{COOH}, \quad \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH}$$
questions.correctAnswer: (a)(i) A = CH₃CHO (Ethanal); B = CH₃CH=NOH (Ethanal oxime). (ii) A = CH₃COOH (Acetic acid); B = CH₃COCl (Acetyl chloride). (b)(i) Benzaldehyde gives silver mirror with Tollen's reagent; acetophenone does not. (ii) HCOOH gives silver mirror with Tollen's reagent; CH₃COOH does not. (c) CH₃CHO < CH₃CH₂OH < CH₃COOH
questions.solution:
(a)(i) Step 1 (A): Rosenmund reduction — acetyl chloride (CH₃COCl) is reduced using H₂ in the presence of Pd-BaSO₄ catalyst to give ethanal (acetaldehyde, CH₃CHO). Step 2 (B): Ethanal reacts with hydroxylamine (H₂N–OH) to give ethanal oxime (CH₃CH=N–OH), an oxime.

(ii) Step 1 (A): Methylmagnesium bromide (Grignard reagent) reacts with CO₂, followed by hydrolysis with H₃O⁺, to give acetic acid (CH₃COOH). Step 2 (B): Acetic acid reacts with PCl₅ to give acetyl chloride (CH₃COCl) along with HCl and POCl₃.

(b)(i) Using Tollen's reagent: C₆H₅–CHO (Benzaldehyde), being an aldehyde, reduces Tollen's reagent to produce a shining silver mirror. C₆H₅–COCH₃ (Acetophenone), being a ketone, does not reduce Tollen's reagent — no silver mirror formed.

(ii) Using Tollen's reagent: HCOOH (Formic acid) reduces Tollen's reagent to give a silver mirror (formic acid has an aldehyde-like –CHO character in its structure). CH₃COOH (Acetic acid) does not reduce Tollen's reagent — no silver mirror formed.

(c) CH₃CHO (Ethanal) has the lowest boiling point as it is a carbonyl compound with only weak dipole–dipole interactions (no O–H hydrogen bonding). CH₃CH₂OH (Ethanol) has a higher boiling point than ethanal due to strong O–H···O hydrogen bonding between alcohol molecules. CH₃COOH (Acetic acid) has the highest boiling point because carboxylic acids form dimers through two strong O–H···O=C hydrogen bonds, requiring the most energy to separate. Order: CH₃CHO < CH₃CH₂OH < CH₃COOH.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Write the chemical reaction involved in Wolff–Kishner reduction.

(b) Arrange the following in the increasing order of their reactivity towards nucleophilic addition reaction:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{COCH}_3, \quad \text{CH}_3\text{-CHO}, \quad \text{CH}_3\text{COCH}_3$$
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (a) R₁-CO-R₂ + H₂NNH₂, Base (KOH), Δ → R₁-CH₂-R₂ (carbonyl group reduced to –CH₂– group). (b) C₆H₅COCH₃ < CH₃COCH₃ < CH₃CHO
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) In Wolff–Kishner reduction, a carbonyl group (–C=O) of an aldehyde or ketone is reduced to a –CH₂– group. The carbonyl compound is first treated with hydrazine (H₂NNH₂) to form a hydrazone (R₁R₂C=NNH₂), which on heating with a base (KOH/ethylene glycol) loses N₂ to give the corresponding alkane. Reaction: R₁-CO-R₂ + H₂NNH₂ (Base, KOH) → R₁R₂C=NNH₂ (hydrazone) → (Δ, -N₂) → R₁-CH₂-R₂.

(b) Nucleophilic addition reactivity depends on steric factors (bulkier groups reduce accessibility for the nucleophile) and electronic factors (electron-withdrawing groups increase electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon). CH₃CHO (aldehyde, less steric hindrance, no electron-donating phenyl group) is most reactive. CH₃COCH₃ (ketone, more steric hindrance than aldehyde but no phenyl group) is intermediate. C₆H₅COCH₃ (has bulky phenyl group causing steric hindrance and also conjugation with carbonyl reducing electrophilicity) is least reactive. Increasing order: C₆H₅COCH₃ < CH₃COCH₃ < CH₃CHO.

questions.question:
For the hydrolysis of methyl acetate in aqueous solution, the following results were obtained:

| $t\ /\ s$ | 0 | 30 | 60 |
|-----------|---|----|----|---|
| $[CH_3COOCH_3]\ /\ mol\ L^{-1}$ | 0.60 | 0.30 | 0.15 |

(i) Show that it follows pseudo first order reaction, as the concentration of water remains constant.
(ii) Calculate the average rate of reaction between the time interval 30 to 60 seconds.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $K_1 = K_2 = \frac{2.303}{30} \log 2$, confirming pseudo first order kinetics.
(ii) Average rate $= 5 \times 10^{-3}\ mol\ L^{-1}\ s^{-1}$
questions.solution:
(i) Proving Pseudo First Order:

Case 1 (at $t = 30\ s$):
$$K_1 = \frac{2.303}{30} \log \frac{0.60}{0.30} = \frac{2.303}{30} \log 2$$

Case 2 (at $t = 60\ s$):
$$K_2 = \frac{2.303}{60} \log \frac{0.60}{0.15} = \frac{2.303}{60} \times 2\log 2 = \frac{2.303}{30} \times \log 2$$

Since $K_1 = K_2$, it confirms that the reaction follows pseudo first order kinetics.

(ii) Average Rate between 30 s and 60 s:
$$\text{Average rate} = -\frac{\Delta R}{\Delta t} = -\left(\frac{0.15 - 0.30}{60 - 30}\right) = \frac{0.15}{30} = 5 \times 10^{-3}\ mol\ L^{-1}\ s^{-1}$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) For a reaction $A + B \rightarrow P$, the rate is given by:
$$\text{Rate} = k[A]^2[B]$$

(i) How is the rate of reaction affected if the concentration of A is doubled?
(ii) What is the overall order of reaction if B is present in large excess?

(b) A first order reaction takes 23.1 minutes for 50% completion. Calculate the time required for 75% completion of this reaction.
(Given: $\log 2 = 0.301$, $\log 3 = 0.4771$, $\log 4 = 0.6021$)
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (a)(i) Rate becomes 4 times. (a)(ii) Overall order = 2. (b) $t = 46.2$ minutes.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a)(i) When concentration of A is doubled:
$$\text{rate}_1 = k[A]^2[B]$$
$$\text{rate}_2 = k[2A]^2[B] = 4k[A]^2[B]$$
The rate becomes 4 times the original rate.

(a)(ii) If B is present in large excess, its concentration remains effectively constant. The reaction appears second order overall (pseudo second order), with order 2 with respect to A.

(b) For 50% completion ($t_{1/2} = 23.1\ min$):
$$K = \frac{2.303}{23.1} \log \frac{100}{50} = \frac{2.303}{23.1} \log 2 \quad \cdots (1)$$

For 75% completion (25% remains):
$$K = \frac{2.303}{t} \log \frac{100}{25} = \frac{2.303}{t} \times 2\log 2 \quad \cdots (2)$$

Dividing equation (1) by equation (2):
$$\frac{t}{23.1 \times 2} = 1$$
$$t = 46.2 \text{ minutes}$$

questions.question:
(a) Account for the following:

(i) Bond angle in $NH_4^+$ is greater than that in $NH_3$.
(ii) Reducing character decreases from $SO_2$ to $TeO_2$.
(iii) $HClO_4$ is a stronger acid than $HClO$.

(b) Draw the structures of the following:

(i) $H_2S_2O_8$
(ii) $XeOF_4$
questions.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) $NH_4^+$ has no lone pair so bond angle is $109°28'$ vs $107°$ in $NH_3$.
(a)(ii) Stability of +4 state increases down the group (inert pair effect), reducing character decreases.
(a)(iii) Higher oxidation state of Cl in $HClO_4$ (+7) makes it stronger acid.
(b)(i) $H_2S_2O_8$: two sulphur atoms connected via peroxy bridge with $=O$ and $-OH$ groups.
(b)(ii) $XeOF_4$: square pyramidal with one $=O$ at apex and four F in equatorial plane.
questions.solution:
(a)(i) In both $NH_4^+$ and $NH_3$, nitrogen is $sp^3$ hybridised. However, in $NH_3$ there is one lone pair which causes lone pair–bond pair (lp–bp) repulsion, reducing the bond angle to $107°$. In $NH_4^+$, there is no lone pair, so only bp–bp repulsions exist, giving a bond angle of $109°28'$.

(a)(ii) Due to the inert pair effect, the stability of the +4 oxidation state increases down the group (S → Se → Te). $TeO_2$ has a more stable lower oxidation state and hence has less tendency to be oxidised further, making it a poor reducing agent. Therefore, reducing character decreases from $SO_2$ to $TeO_2$.

(a)(iii) In $HClO_4$, the oxidation state of Cl is $+7$, and in $HClO$ it is $+1$. Higher oxidation state and greater number of oxygen atoms in $HClO_4$ results in greater electron withdrawal from the O–H bond, making it easier to release $H^+$. Hence $HClO_4$ is a stronger acid.

(b)(i) Structure of $H_2S_2O_8$ (Peroxodisulphuric acid / Marshall's acid):
Two sulphur atoms each in tetrahedral geometry, connected via a peroxy ($-O-O-$) bridge. Each S has two $=O$ groups and one $-OH$ group:
$$HO - \overset{\displaystyle O}{\overset{\displaystyle \|}{S}} - O - O - \overset{\displaystyle O}{\overset{\displaystyle \|}{S}} - OH$$
with additional $=O$ on each S.

(b)(ii) Structure of $XeOF_4$:
Xe at centre with square pyramidal geometry. One $=O$ at apex, four F atoms in equatorial plane, one lone pair on Xe pointing downward (opposite to O). Shape is square pyramidal.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Which poisonous gas is evolved when white phosphorus is heated with conc. NaOH solution? Write the chemical equation.

(b) Write the formula of first noble gas compound prepared by N. Bartlett. What inspired N. Bartlett to prepare this compound?

(c) Fluorine is a stronger oxidizing agent than chlorine. Why?

(d) Write one use of chlorine gas.

(e) Complete the following equation: $CaF_2 + H_2SO_4 \rightarrow$
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a) $PH_3$ (Phosphine); $P_4 + 3NaOH + 3H_2O \longrightarrow PH_3 + 3NaH_2PO_2$
(b) $Xe^+PtF_6^-$; inspired by $O_2^+PtF_6^-$ and similar ionisation enthalpies of $O_2$ and Xe.
(c) Low bond dissociation enthalpy of F-F and high hydration enthalpy of $F^-$.
(d) Sterilising/purifying drinking water.
(e) $CaF_2 + H_2SO_4 \longrightarrow CaSO_4 + 2HF$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) $$P_4 + 3NaOH + 3H_2O \longrightarrow PH_3 + 3NaH_2PO_2$$
Poisonous gas: $PH_3$ (Phosphine)

(b) Formula of first noble gas compound: $Xe^+PtF_6^-$
N. Bartlett first prepared the compound $O_2^+PtF_6^-$. He then realised that the first ionisation enthalpy of molecular oxygen $(1175\ KJ\ mol^{-1})$ was almost identical with that of xenon $(1170\ KJ\ mol^{-1})$. This inspired him to make efforts to prepare a similar compound with Xe, and he successfully prepared the red-coloured compound $Xe^+PtF_6^-$.

(c) Fluorine is a stronger oxidizing agent than chlorine due to:
- Low bond dissociation enthalpy of F-F bond (easily dissociates)
- High hydration enthalpy of $F^-$ ion
Both factors make the reduction of $F_2$ thermodynamically more favourable.

(d) Use of chlorine gas: In sterilising/purifying drinking water.

(e) $$CaF_2 + H_2SO_4 \longrightarrow CaSO_4 + 2HF$$

questions.question:
An aromatic compound A of molecular formula $C_7H_7ON$ undergoes a series of reactions as shown below. Write the structures of A, B, C, D and E in the following reactions:

$(C_7H_7ON)\ A \xrightarrow{Br_2/KOH} C_6H_5NH_2 \xrightarrow{NaNO_2+HCl} B \xrightarrow{CuCN} C$

$C_6H_5NH_2 \xrightarrow{CHCl_3 + NaOH} D$

$B \xrightarrow{H_2O} E$
questions.correctAnswer: A: $C_6H_5CONH_2$ (Benzamide), B: $C_6H_5N_2^+Cl^-$ (Benzene diazonium chloride), C: $C_6H_5CN$ (Benzonitrile), D: $C_6H_5NC$ (Phenyl isocyanide), E: $C_6H_5COOH$ (Benzoic acid)
questions.solution:
Structures of A, B, C, D and E:

A: $C_6H_5CONH_2$ (Benzamide) — molecular formula $C_7H_7ON$. Undergoes Hofmann bromamide degradation with $Br_2/KOH$ to give aniline ($C_6H_5NH_2$).

B: $C_6H_5N_2^+Cl^-$ (Benzene diazonium chloride) — obtained by diazotisation of aniline with $NaNO_2 + HCl$.

C: $C_6H_5CN$ (Benzonitrile) — obtained by Sandmeyer reaction of B with CuCN.

D: $C_6H_5NC$ (Phenyl isocyanide / carbylamine) — obtained by carbylamine reaction of aniline with $CHCl_3 + NaOH$.

E: $C_6H_5COOH$ (Benzoic acid) — obtained by hydrolysis of benzene diazonium chloride (B) with water.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(a) Write the structures of the main products when aniline reacts with the following reagents:

(i) $Br_2$ water
(ii) $HCl$
(iii) $(CH_3CO)_2O\ /\ pyridine$

(b) Arrange the following in the increasing order of their boiling point:
$C_2H_5NH_2,\ C_2H_5OH,\ (CH_3)_3N$

(c) Give a simple chemical test to distinguish between the following pair of compounds:
$(CH_3)_2NH$ and $(CH_3)_3N$
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a)(i) 2,4,6-tribromoaniline + 3HBr
(a)(ii) Anilinium chloride $C_6H_5\overset{+}{N}H_3Cl^-$
(a)(iii) Acetanilide ($C_6H_5NHCOCH_3$)
(b) $(CH_3)_3N < C_2H_5NH_2 < C_2H_5OH$
(c) Use Hinsberg's reagent: $(CH_3)_2NH$ reacts, $(CH_3)_3N$ does not.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a)(i) Aniline + $Br_2$ water:
$C_6H_5NH_2 + 3Br_2 \xrightarrow{H_2O}$ 2,4,6-tribromoaniline $+ 3HBr$
The $-NH_2$ group strongly activates the ring, causing tribromination at ortho and para positions.

(a)(ii) Aniline + HCl:
$C_6H_5NH_2 + HCl \longrightarrow C_6H_5\overset{+}{N}H_3Cl^-$ (Anilinium chloride)
Aniline acts as a base and accepts a proton from HCl.

(a)(iii) Aniline + $(CH_3CO)_2O$ / pyridine:
$C_6H_5NH_2 + (CH_3CO)_2O \xrightarrow{Py} C_6H_5NHCOCH_3 + CH_3COOH$
Acetanilide is formed by acetylation.

(b) Increasing order of boiling points:
$(CH_3)_3N < C_2H_5NH_2 < C_2H_5OH$
Reason: Ethanol has the highest boiling point due to strong hydrogen bonding. Ethylamine forms hydrogen bonds but weaker than alcohol. Trimethylamine cannot form H-bonds (no N–H), so it has the lowest boiling point.

(c) Chemical test using Hinsberg's reagent ($C_6H_5SO_2Cl$ — benzenesulphonyl chloride):
- $(CH_3)_2NH$ (secondary amine) reacts with Hinsberg's reagent to form a sulphonamide product (insoluble in NaOH):
$(CH_3)_2NH + C_6H_5SO_2Cl \longrightarrow (CH_3)_2N-SO_2-C_6H_5 + HCl$
- $(CH_3)_3N$ (tertiary amine) does not react with Hinsberg's reagent (no N–H bond available).
This difference in reactivity distinguishes the two compounds.
